description:
Cute little unique spot. Looks unassuming outside but transports you to a different era when you go in. Go here for a unique experience.

I was here for afternoon tea. Loved the old music they were playing.  Got tea, scones and warm chocolate orange lava cake.  Loved the old world cutlery they served it in. 

Side note - it is old but could use a deep cleaning.
author: Sunil R.

description:
This place is extremely understaffed so the service was very slow. Compared to many other high teas, the quantity and quality of food was severely lacking. There are not many vegetarian options--we ordered one of the Kings courses to be vegetarian but apart from the sandwiches we ordered all the other food was not vegetarian. The scones don't come with jam. They also charge split fees and a 20% service fee. 

The tea was good and some of the sweets were decent. The decor was very cute!
author: Waanmathi V.

description:
Adorable space with tasty food and tea, but was woefully understaffed. The only hostess/waitress/busser was running all over the place the whole time and a 1 person tea service (for which all pastries were most likely premade) took 50 minutes to serve. We had to correct hostess/waitress/busser on our bill twice. I felt bad, she was obviously super busy. Honestly came off as overwhelmed. 

We noticed we stayed 40 mins past closing after the fact, which we felt bad about, but staff didn't inform us of this at any point. They should have a policy in place for this to make things easier on themselves. 

Also: pricing + split fees are confusing, which wouldn't have been as annoying if staff was able to take the time to walk us through things & tell us how much our meal would actually cost as we were ordering.
author: Maya S.

description: This place was good, but not amazing unfortunately. I had called in and had to make a reservations, but once my mom and I entered we saw that the place was completely empty. I felt that it was over priced for the tea and you have to purchase minimum amounts in order to get certain items. When you share items too there is a fee to do that so you end up paying half of an additional order just to share. We ordered a tea pot and shared a dessert, but the dessert did not seem that fresh. Overall I would say it is a place to maybe have some overpriced tea and get some cool tea party type of photos. I think I may have had a better experience coming with a group and ordering the towers of snacks and desserts and going all out, but of course would have paid so much more for it!
author: Sophia K.

description:
I've been to a few different high teas around the world - mostly in my home town of London (and a couple in India) and was excited to take my girlfriend to one in San Francisco. 

This place is located in gritty SoMa, we parked on a metered spot outside the venue, adjacent to a pool of broken glass and walked in on a sunny Californian Sunday at around noon. Despite every table being reserved, we were the first party to visit.

The decor and crockery were a colourful mish mash of different china sets and furniture, not unlike what you'd accumulate if you exclusively collected second hand dining sets. This was more quirky than anything else, but lacked the refinement of the more formal teas elsewhere.

The tea menu itself felt pricey at around $35 per person (give or take) for your choice of one tea, a couple of savoury dishes, some finger sandwiches, a scone with cream and some small pastries. Yes, it's cheaper than going to one of the high teas in London but at those, they generally bring more food than you can possibly eat and you have the option of multiple teas. Plus, there's something to be said for the ambience of a 5* hotel versus that of a ground floor restaurant in SoMa...

All in all, I'd recommend going once, but maybe not twice.
author: Sunil S.

description:
I have a lovely time at Dartealing. It is a super cute space that is perfect for a tea party. The scones were to die for and everything else was good too. But the scones and tea were just amazing.

Three stars because I had an 11am appointment and the restaurant didn't open until 11:10am when we went and knocked on the back door. The whole place only had one server. So I didn't eat or drink any tea until 12pm.... we sat there for almost a hour before we even got our tea.

However I would return, I loved my experience.
author: Tina L.

description: Excellent place for afternoon tea.  I've been to many of tea rooms in SF, Seattle, Vancouver, and Boston, London, DC. This is not a traditional tea room with swan shaped cream puffs. It's a place where all of the food is thoughtfully designed.  It's a perfect combination of fanciful and comfortable. The service is consistently good. Go now and often.
author: Annie K.

description:
I love tea rooms and have been here twice now. Both times the customer service was outstanding and their selection of teas and food is great. Tea rooms in SF definitely don't compare to the ones in the UK, but they give you a good idea and glimpse of what it would be like.

There were 4 of us and 2 of us got the King's menu and 2 got the Queen's menu. Each come with their own pot of tea. The tea menu is easy to read and easily distinguishes the ones that are caffeinated versus decaffeinated. The food tray is very well portioned, with a variety of sweet and savory. You get to choose from a selection of tea sandwiches and you cant go wrong with any of them. They are fun to eat and tasty! 

The decor of this place is great. It is on par with other tea rooms in SF, but I just love it. Can't wait to go back.
author: Cicely T.

description:
Cheerio, pip-pip and all that rot. Having English-style high tea seems like such an anomaly in SoMa and yet, here it is, a proper tea room in hipster central. Spit-spot. I had to convince Jamie W. that this would be an experience to treasure since we've been on a tea binge of late. Considering this was obviously not once a Victorian-era parlor, the owners have done a fine job furnishing what was obviously just a plain room with hardwood floors into something where you could picture Vanessa Redgrave sitting with Emma Thompson in 1910 London (photo: http://bit.ly/2rEXfXf).

Big hats and gloves would be involved, you know. Cute name by the by. A little too cute. I get the Darjeeling tea connection. Would you be impressed if I told you I've been to Darjeeling? Yeah, I didn't think so. We were there for tea and not finger sandwiches, scones, or crumpets. Those edibles looked elegantly good in fancy triple tier servers, but we just wanted tea. We did notice that the menu stated a $14 per person dining minimum, but the kindly server luckily didn't hold us to it since it wasn't fully packed on a late Sunday afternoon (photo: http://bit.ly/2rFbOtX).

We ordered an $8 pot of a hearty fruit herbal tea called Painted Ladies since it offered an infusion of berries and sweet apples (photo: http://bit.ly/2pXPPlh). The tea set definitely came from Grandma's house or at least a nice consignment store selling Victorian-era china. It was a tasteful hodgepodge of porcelain (photo: http://bit.ly/2q5quSC). The space looks like it accommodates large parties or just couples and at least one laptopper who must have thought he landed in one weird Starbucks. Their afternoon teas range from $33 to $48, so when Vanessa and Emma are in town, I know where we'll go.

TEA - 4 stars...lovely loose leaf tea in a "Howard's End"-type setting except it's a refurbished SoMa space
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...spit-spot
SERVICE - 4 stars...very nice to us, the last of the big spenders
TOTAL - 4 stars...if you are looking for a bit of Victorian London in SoMa, then blimey, you're in luck
author: Ed U.

description: This...was a very weird experience. The place is very much outfitted in what I imagine an Alice in Wonderland/cottagey feel. However, there are many rules that are not very clearly delineated with regard to the tea. For example, there is a minimum charge per person that can't be satisfied by the split additional fee charge. The tea was great but we weren't super impressed by the petit fours, and the person came by only occasionally. We tried to change our order (since she had suggested we get a particular thing to hit the minimum, but we realized we wanted something else) two minutes after ordering and she was pretty annoyed.
author: Heidi L.

description:
Stopped in recently for a relaxing cup of tea on my way to Caltrain. The tea itself was expensive, but quite good: ordered Parisian Earl grey.

The place is mostly selling ambiance, which has potential but needs a lot of work. When I first walked in, the air smelled extremely stake, but either I got used to it quickly or the staff noticed too and opened a window. Place is decorated in French Country style, but there is significant dust, plastic tabs of some sort stuck to the ceiling where something used to hang, and the curtains and chandelier chain covers were never ironed to remove the fold creases. The walls are scratched where chairs hit them, and some of the windows are broken and taped, and graffitid. The combination of all this makes the place feel a little dirty, not cozy.

Finally, the service wasn't great. I think the one waitress was overworked and kind if tired. She wasn't rude at all, just mostly indifferent. It took a little over 10 minutes between ordering and getting my tea, but I expect most customers come here to relax and take their time.

Honestly, I think the place deserves only 3 stars, but I  want an independent small business like this to do well, and I think they could improve a lot with a few changes.
author: Christopher N.

description:
Sunday tea service for 2 and we ordered the King's tea service since the server recommended it for first timers.  Two choices in tea sandwiches and we chose the curried chicken mango chutney and honey lavender creme.  For teas, it was Wolves of Winterfell and Kings Landing.  This may not seem too important but their steeped loose so you have to use a strainer for your cup.  Not a huge deal but just the first time I ever had to do that (I've been to a couple of other tea rooms).  
The teas came out first and we really liked the Wolves of Winterfell, rooibos with hints of toffee and caramel.  Kings Landing was ok, it wasn't too strong in the mango flavor.  
The food came out in a two tiered tray - the sweets were on top and savories on the bottom.  There were two different scones and both were pretty good.  The sandwiches were good, nothing outstanding but I did like the variety in selection choices.  Tomato spinach quiche and sausage rolls were nice and we were already getting full and warm due to the many cups of tea we were having.
The place wasn't entirely full that afternoon and we noticed there was only 1 server - hard to get her attention though.
The place has a very cutesy feel to it and agree with other yelpers that you can't tell from the outside.  
It was still a good experience but I wouldn't go out of my way to come here next time.  Since I'm from the East Bay, I'll stick with the one closest to me, the English Rose in Pleasanton.
author: Debbie H.

description: I came here by myself in the middle of the day to study. It was very empty, only two other parties of two people each. The decor is charming but borderline too much stuff. It didn't seem WiFi friendly or really a place to study. It's more of a place to meet a friend and talk. If you have a large party I would definitely call ahead of time so that they can put together a table for you. The location seemed a bit out of the way of things but I found that actually pleasant. Perfect spot to just get away from the crowds without going too far. The scones were absolutely amazing! And of a very good size. If you're not starving, these are perfect with a side of cream. MUST GET THE CREAM! In addition they were served warm! They also have a nice tea selection, all cutely named.
author: Christine T.

description:
I have been to a lot of tea places all over the Bay Area, and I consistently come back to Dartealing. I think they have better food and more creative, delicious tea flavors than any other tea place I've been to. Their store is also very cute and kitschy, which is a nice environment to have tea in.

I removed one star because the staff have been less than friendly in the past. I arranged a private tea event once and was left feeling like, rather than bringing in business, I was a nuisance to them to asking questions and getting quotes - even after I paid. Recently I went to a tea here hosted by a friend and she had the same experience; the service was so poor she felt the need to apologize to the guests.

Also note that inside is always extremely warm. Dead of winter, middle of the summer, it's always about 80 degrees inside before you even sit down and start drinking hot liquid.
author: L U.

description: This little tea house was very cute inside and the tea and food was very good. The service was slow and the tables were close together so on a busy day this is not the ideal place for a quiet tea time, luckily there are many tables and we didn't run into this issue. It very much reminded me of grandmas house with the old fashioned decor and cute mismatched tea sets. The old phrase "you get what you paid for" applies in this instance. If you are expecting the Ritz you will be disappointed. The price aligns well with the level of fanciness at $29 a head for 2+ people. This would be the perfect place to bring a little girl for her first tea and I felt like it was very affordable.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Eating at Dartealing is like stepping into a cute Alice in Wonderland setting. I love the antique decor, tea pots and comfortable lounge seating. It's great for a long, social brunch with friends. I'm disappointed they took the main entrees away, I really enjoyed eating the croque monsieur especially because I'm a fan of more savory food.

We tried the tea service, matcha cheesecake and various tea breads and sandwiches. The tea bread was pretty good, the scones and cookies didn't feel so fresh. The curried chicken sandwich is my favorite! Overall, really enjoyed the different selections and tea but felt like the service was really lacking. We had to call them over several times to order and pay and the restaurant really wasn't that busy. Dartealing is a bit too expensive for my likes considering the service and quality of some of the pastries.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Met friends  @ their suggestion.

Decor...low ceiling like an old basement, but has windows.
Neighborhood...typical SOMA
Service...fine.

$40 per person...for a pot of tea, & a few mediocre mini sandwiches!!!
Afterwards we unanimously agreed...why pay so much, & get so little!

Bottom line...not worth 1/2 that price.

Would never...repeat never return!
author: Saul M.

description:
Cute place, mediocre food/tea, horrible service. 

They have an impressive and extensive tea selection. We tried four teas- Parisian Earl Grey, Bridge Over the River Chai, "The Woman", and Checkmate, Mycroft! None of them were memorable. The Earl Grey was the best out of the four with the most flavor. I love Chai and was the most excited about it. It was also the most disappointing with absolutely no "bold spice" or "sweet citrus aroma" like it promised. 

The food took an hour to come out, that is with a reservation so everything was pre-ordered! We ordered Ham Gouda Honey Mustard, Smoked Salmon Mousse, Turkey Pesto Cream, and Cucumber Arugula. Again, none stood out to me. Out of the four, the turkey pesto cream was my favorite, and the smoked salmon mousse had no salmon taste to it. The scones were the highlight of the meal- we had taro and raspberry scones that were unique. Don't think I would return.
author: Peggy L.

description:
I'm somewhat of a high tea fanatic. Every city I'm in I seek them out. It's lovely to have a handful of places to chose from in SF! I've tried Lovejoy's and Crown & Crumpet, so now it was high time (get it?) to try here.

It's a really cute place, but small, so a reservation is encouraged (more on that below). I love that they have mismatched furniture and table settings. Just adds to the allure.

I like that their tea sandwiches are a mix of traditional while the majority are pretty creative. I could have probably ate my weight in the BLT sandwiches, they were by far the best. The pumpkin scones were fresh out of the oven and delicious. I liked the assorted sweet treats, but the scones and the BLT sandwich won the best food award.

I chose Her Majesty's tea and liked it so much I ended up purchasing a tin to take home! I'm a big fan of black tea that's bold and you can add milk to. 

I will note I called and left at least three messages to make a reservation and got no call back. I ended up calling about a half hour before they opened and pretty much begged them to seat us. They "said" they were full but when I mentioned I'd called several times, they must have took pity on me and squeezed us in. Just beware, you may have to stalk them for a rez.
author: Rachel C.

description:
We were so excited to have tea here. We were let down. I am not sure how this place has a four star rating.  The servers were indifferent and mostly absent, wearing workout clothes with tacky sayings on their t-shirts. We waited 45 minutes before any food came out and were then told they were 'baking' the sweets, sorry for the wait. We didn't see our server again until the sweets came.  The sweets, scone, crumpet, various random desserts were NOT freshly baked. The mini eclairs were straight from Costco and were frozen, macaroons also from Costco.  The 'sweet cream' was not sweet but tasted like it was cut with cream cheese.  
The sandwiches were flavorful but they were just on white bread with the crusts cut off, nothing that warranted the $7 per sandwich price. Same with the sweets, don't charge $52 for a sweets assortment that isn't made in house.

The tea was an herbal tea and was weak, it never really steeped well or change color, it also had no flavor. I'm not sure they understand how tea really works.

The decor is sloppy. Upon arrival it has a vibe like it used to be a sushi bar but then they added all this kitschy 'tea room' stuff so now it's a tea room. It's NOT a team room.

We had to hunt down someone to get a check, after we had been there for two hours. The staff was just hanging around in the back.

It was a very disappointing experience and the four star reviews are just mystifying. Go to the Sheraton, Samovar, Fairmont or even Lovejoy but NOT this spot.
author: Elaina S.

description:
I met up with some ladies from school at Dartealing recently. To be honest, this wasn't our first choice but other places booked up so quickly, especially during the holidays. Dartealing accommodated our group, even with some last minute cancellations. We got 4 types of teas: Earl de Versailles, La Belle Epoque, Chamomile on the Veranda, and Brown-Eyed Girl. Aren't these names so cute?

They were accompanied by the following tea sandwiches: Smoked Salmon Mouse Capers, Brie Apple Sweet Pepper Jelly, Hummus Red Pepper Mediterranean, Creamy Danish Blue Arugula Fig, and Chicken Apple Cranberry. The sandwiches were all very tasty.

I enjoyed the scone the most and although there were some sweets on top of the platter, I appreciated the ratio of savory to sweet munchies.

If you like Lovejoy's and did not plan a month in advance, Dartealing is the most comparable option in the City. The location is easily accessible for those who are coming from the East Bay or the Peninsula as well. This place should get more recognition than it does. I really like it.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Yummm. We did the Convent Garden and Knightsbridge which had a good mix of savory and sweet. Our sandwiches were something curry and they were both delicious. I wasn't a fan of the From Amsterdam with Love tea (not enough flavor) but the Cabana Boys made up for it - flavorful with a hint of fruits.

The place decor was....I'm at a loss for words. Tons of flowery kettles and teacups everywhere, it seemed like every piece of the wall was decorated with something - kind of busy look but also fun.

We got there a little before opening on Saturday and had to wait about 5-10 minutes AFTER it opened before anybody opened the doors. I didn't make a reservation so I was worried we wouldn't be able to get a table. But I guess there's enough Afternoon Tea places in SF that we didn't have to go super early, I'm sure if we had just wandered in it would've been fine.

Overall, I would definitely come back.
author: Truc N.

description:
10/29/16:  I believe I misplaced something.... damn... checked the car... all over the house... now come on, where is that man card I used to have!?!?

The last thing I remember was going to some pretty place with 3 hot girls, being surrounded by porcelain, embroidery, and fancy silverware....... and I think I passed out sometime after they started yapping in a language that just seemed to make my lower regions shrink...

Hmmm... well, it's sorta coming back to me that we had ordered... "Covent Garden" Afternoon Tea $56 for 2, and "Knightsbridge" High Tea $62 for 2.

Yeah... yeah.... I remember now... after our waitress came by with 4 beautiful pots of fancy teas, after she took another 20min after, she placed a 2 tier silver platter stand with little cutely cut sandwiches and small snacks on our table........

And yeah.......... I think it was then some math formed in my head, contemplating whether I added $56 and $62 together correctly to make $118.  Cause, well, 2 plates of sandwiches, toasts, desserts, and tea for $118 seems just sooooooo.......... my god, I did add right!...... and WHAM I think my head hit the floor and there I remained for the remainder of this odd odd and odd dream.

4/5

#noontea #englishtea #teatime #hightea #afternoontea #sanfrancisco
author: Dean C.

description:
This place has a few positives, but more substantial negatives.

Positives:
-Friendly service.
-Lots of tea options.
-Amazing set-up (furniture, decorations, etc.).

Negatives:
-VERY expensive. If you want to just SHARE the "Knightsbridge" High Tea, you both have to pay $35, which is insane. If you're getting one for yourself, it's $39. That ratio makes 0 sense. My friend and I wanted to try it but definitely did not want to pay $35 each. Also, the pricing for the tea pots is weird too. If you share 1 tea pot with one guest, they add a $4 sharing fee on top of the $8 price for the pot?! Are you serious? This place is not worth the $.
-The savory sandwiches are good, but the sweet ones are HORRIBLE. I would not recommend the berries & cream one - it did not taste like berries.
-The sandwiches they serve you are so tiny. $9 for that does not make sense.
-They don't ask you what kind of milk you want. They just put whole milk on the table for you. They should ask before assuming that's what you want.

I probably won't come back.
author: Remy B.

description: Honestly, I was really disappointed, but it may be because I had really high expectations after going to the high tea at the Rotunda in Neiman Marcus in Union Square. All of the food did not taste fresh except the replacement sandwich I got after finding a curly, brown hair in the first. The sweets were either hard or tasted like they had been made a while ago. The best part was the tea. Just overall, very underwhelming and disappointing experience.
author: Kaylynn C.

description: Super cute place to gather with friends and enjoy tea. The food and the service were good, my only suggestion would be that staff dress more in line with the tea service.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I felt as though I was in a dollhouse! This is such a cute and quaint venue for tea. We had a party of eight and the servers were very attentive and friendly. We got a variety of sandwiches - from what I can remember, there was a salmon, pesto turkey (my favourite!), a hummus, and a ham and cheese (did not try) - and all were so delicious! As for the tea - Breakfast Candy was my ultimate favourite. It is a black tea loaded with flavour. We also got Mr. Carson's Secret Stash, Cheeky Mango Monkey (the table favourite), and Royal Earl Grey. All were really good and the staff were always there with refills when we got a little low on the tea. 
Albeit, the feel of this place is a bit casual, feel free to dress up and wear fancy hats! 

Additional note- we went on a Saturday (had a reservation) around 1pm and both traffic and parking were a breeze. There is plenty of street (metered) parking on the side street next to the lounge but I believe it was fifty cents an hour, so not bad at all.
author: Keenya D.

description: Authentic tea cups, flavorful tea (love the names! Hope there was a connection between the tea and the names). Lots of options too. The decor is unique with relaxing instrumental music in the background. Good spot to hang with friends and chat. Didn't eat food here, so look forward to dropping by again to check out the food.
author: Akhil K.

description: Great place. We got the king's tea with an extra sandwich. For tea we had the three eyed crow (limited edition I believe) and the Parisian Earl grey. First of all those sandwiches. Oh my god. I am obsessed with soft white bread and the fillings were just so good. We got the bacon potato chives, curry chicken and smoked salmon mousse flavors. All were amazing but the potato flavor was the best. Everything was just so good especially paired with the tea. The servings are deceptively small, as we couldn't even finish a lot of the desserts and we were still pretty full a couple hours later after walking through Golden gate Park the entire time. The decorations and the porcelain are very cute, and there is some serious caffeine in this tea, although it might just be because I am very sensitive to caffeine and usually only drink green teas. The Parisian Earl grey was really nice, especially with a little milk, although I had to stop adding milk because it was making me even  more full. The three eyed crow tasted like hot chocolate especially with milk added, it was pretty interesting. It's a cute place with great teas and great food, highly recommended
author: Michelle Z.

description: I am usually a huge fan of Dartealing, but I do not like their winter solstice menu. The options are very limited. Dartealing, although expensive, is very cute. I love the mismatched chairs, cutlery, cups, everything. This is how I imagine my cafe if I ever opened one. Simply adorable. Teas are really yummy as well. Strange that they do not have a variety of milk. I asked for soy, but they didn't have it. I believe they only have whole milk. A tad strange.. Customer is consistently not great. They're not very attentive even if you're the only ones there.
author: Mallory L.

description:
We celebrated my friend's birthday at Dartealing Lounge.  We were glad that we had a reservation because the small place was full.  The decor is nice and the service was fine. The sandwiches were delicious especially the salmon mousse and the turkey pesto.  The bread was very fresh.  There was an extensive selection of teas.  I ordered a pot from the "Downtown Abbey" group and enjoyed it.  The meal was more filling than I expected and we couldn't finish everything. 

There were 2 large groups (10 - 12 @) and one of them in particular was very loud!!  Their boisterous conversations and laughter was inappropriate for a small tea house. I don't have any suggestions as to how such a situation could be handled.  But I hope that the staff can figure out a way to handle such situations in the future.  Despite the delicious food and teas, the noise ruined the atmosphere for me and I'm not enthusiastic about returning.  There are lots of fine places to eat in our City.
author: Andrea P.

description:
After spending the other week in London and having afternoon tea almost daily, I was having major tea party withdrawals.  Thanks to Dartealing Lounge, I was able to put those withdrawal feelings to rest and made some last minute resies.  I made the reservations for 4 people a couple of days before (The Rotunda and The Palace were both fully booked), and I was even running late and changed the appointment the day of 2x!

The ambiance is charming, quirky, girly, and eclectic.  I loved the mismatched furniture and equally mismatched tea pots and serving ware.  If you've been to a Lisa's Tea Treasures, I'd say Dartealing Lounge is quite comparable in terms of decor.  

Initially, my friends and I were confused about the way to order and the pricing - but in the end it all seemed to work out.  We were all pretty full so we ordered 4 types of sandwiches (cut into quarter slices, a cinnamon bread, matcha cheesecake, and 3 pots of tea.  The sandwiches were all light and good.  My favorite was the blue cheese one....if you love blue cheese, I highly recommend it!  However, the salmon sandwich could have used a little bit more salmon.  All three teas we had were delicious (Sorry, I can't remember the names).  We started with a green tea with tropical notes, continued with a green tea with floral notes, and then ended with a black tea with chocolate flavors.  Though not entirely intentional, the way we paired our teas and sandwiches worked out nicely!

One thing to note is that the area isn't really the nicest area - Dartealing is located under a freeway overpass and as soon as my Uber pulled up, there were 5 cop cars surrounding the building...
author: Lisa Marie R.

description:
If Lovejoy's is a cozy grandma's attic, Dartealing would be a section of the grandma's attic where mold grows.

Setting: How should I put this... ghetto
- Claustrophobic
- Bathroom echoes divey chinese restaurant with zero cutesy and questionable hygiene
- One of our teacups came with leftover thread stuck inside, reminiscient of tampon strings but likely from a teabag
- Bare F---s given to decorative detail, mass-market spoons to stir your tea instead of standard stirring silverware

Service: DGAF
- First waitress begrudgingly helped take our pictures, pics came out blurry as an acid trip
- Second waitress begrudgingly helped take our pictures, pics came out without our heads
- Milk turned into a bunch of white curds in one of our teas. Upon request, waitress explained the whole acidic tea + milk = precipitation science. Good to know, except she then shuffled away without offering a new cup, perhaps expecting us to just drink all the acid milk shit
- Our two waitresses carried Eeyore's enthusiasm the entire time, sad place for a meal

Food: Standard
- Good curry chicken sandwich
- You can find everything else and more at less moldy grandma's attics

Bye.
author: Tian Q.

description:
The place is cute, but I can say the food was not the main attraction.

Tea = Okay

Foods = Below Average

It's a really fun place for girlfriends and catching up.  I tried the peach tea, the jasmine tea and the rooibos tea.  They were all good - jasmine is definitely more of the "you can find anywhere" so I'd recommend going for more exciting teas.  

The pricing of the tastings were a bit high - food bites included.  It starts at $27.  I would stick with the basic tea tasting of sandwiches if I were you.  The day I was there, they didn't have some items from the Knightsbridge High Tea, but neglected to tell the table so that was a little disappointing.  And even without the English sausage roll, I was charged for the full price.  If I knew, I would have ordered something else.  The sandwiches were on the dry side without enough filling.  The scones were on the tiny side.  For what you pay for, I was expecting so much more.
author: Julie C.

description:
My friends and I (total of 7) had a really nice time. The staff were very accommodating and reasonably timely to bring the tea and food to our table.
Hats off to the savory's, they were delicious!
There is a vast array of teas to choose from and I especially like the witty tea names acquired by the themes such as, Game of Thrones and Sherlock Holmes. I highly recommend the Wolves of Waterfell tea, I couldn't stop drinking it. The child's tea service was so cute. It included a child size teapot filled with a very flavorful Earl Grey tea and a beautiful stand filled with fresh fruit and sandwich segments, topped with a candle, very impressive. I would definitely visit again. 
I would offer one critique that my group all agreed upon, that it would be awesome to have had at least one table (per theme) each designed to mimic the theme teas they offered. A Game of Thrones table decorated as such while drinking Wolves of Winterfell tea would be amazing! Hint, hint.
author: Gayle T.

description:
The interior is very cute - totally princess movie, English cozy tea room, dolls and tea time kind of a vibe. Pink lace and fluffy things all over, low ceiling, and cozied up lounging chairs and sofas. We came as a big group, so the service was definitely slow, but the waitress also looked like she hated our guts. or just having a bad day - who knows. 

Tea: I had the black tea, green tea, herbal tea, and some other vanilla scented black tea that was the best out of the four. The tea was rather weak and uninteresting to me. 

Snacks, scones, sandwiches: The food was very, very okay. Nothing awful about it, but wouldn't come back for it. The four types of sandwiches that we got were smoked salmon, gruyere, curried eggs, and brie/jelly/pepper. They skimped out on the salmon, the brie and jelly weren't very evenly distributed so each bite was off, and the bread was dry. The desserts were too sweet, but the scones were good.
author: Grace P.

description:
TLDR - cozy spot for afternoon tea, come for the ambiance and company here more than the tea or food

My friend and I stopped by for a late afternoon tea around 4pm on a rainy Sunday. It was pretty busy, but we were lucky enough to have a table open up shortly after we got there. I'd definitely recommend making a reservation beforehand, especially if you have a group larger than 2 people.

Dartealing is a pretty cute, cozy spot located kind of randomly in SOMA, not really around anything at all. The only other tea lounge I've been to in SF is Samovar and compared to that one, which was more trendy, Dartealing has more of that quintessential afternoon tea vibe with its floral, patterned tea pots and cups.

They have a LOT of unique teas to choose from, full tea services and food a la carte. Honestly though, the tea wasn't particularly special. Maybe my friend and I just didn't pick the right ones. We asked for recommendations and went with two of them, but weren't very impressed.

We ordered the BLOOMSBURY FULL TEA for 2 ($52), which included 2 pots of tea, 4 tea sandwiches, green salad, tea bread, scones, macarons and shortbread cookies.

For our tea, we got:
     * DEBUTANTE BALL [subtle floral notes of jasmine, rose, creamy undertones, smooth finish] - I love floral teas so I went with this one for the jasmine and rose, but I guess the description wasn't kidding when it said "subtle" because I couldn't taste anything floral at all. It really just tasted like plain green tea to me, and a really light green tea if anything.
     * LAST MANGO IN PARIS [special blend of red rooibos with ripe, juicy mango] - My friend opted for a fruity tea. The mango was definitely noticeable, but I wasn't a huge fan.

For our sandwiches, we got:
     * SMOKED SALMON MOUSSE & DILL - We each ordered the smoked salmon because we both lovee smoked salmon. We didn't realize it was going to be mostly mousse though, so we were unfortunately pretty disappointed. Some of the sandwiches had a tiny bit of smoked salmon but otherwise it was mostly a creamy, mayo-like paste.
     * TURKEY & PESTO CREAM - Pretty much what you would expect: slices of turkey with pesto.
     * DARTEALING CURRIED CHICKEN - Kind of like the salmon in the sense that it was more of a paste/spread rather than actual chicken. Maybe more like very, very shredded chicken. Flavor is pretty good though so I'd recommend it if you like savory food

I really enjoyed all of the sweets too. The tea bread was some sort of yummy banana bread. The scones had a nice crispness on the outside and soft, fluffiness on the inside. The macarons were perfectly chewy!

My general impression though is that afternoon tea is really more about the atmosphere and the hours you spend chatting with your friends and less about the tea service itself, despite it being a tea lounge. I've been to Samovar in SF and Tea Time in Palo Alto and felt the same at both places as well. Not really complaining though. I still love taking time for afternoon tea, but $26 each is pretty pricey for some light tea and food, so I'd recommend just ordering a pot of tea and something separate to eat rather than a full tea service.
author: Jessie L.

description: The food is good but the service has gone downhill. If you have a group of 5 people's orders on one tea tray it seems like it's set up for failure. All the sandwiches were wrong e.g. ham when no one ordered ham and if two people order vegetarian things they of course bring everyone veg stuff and accuse you of saying you also wanted veg. Pretty annoying won't go back. Also it's louder than a bar in there the way the acoustics are so don't expect quiet tea time!
author: Maya G.

description:
Starting with the positive, this place is adorable - probably the prettiest of the tea rooms that have been in SF over the past 20 years.  And I've been to every one of them as they have come and gone.  It's also very clean, and proudly display their inspection score card that earned 100!  Also my black tea with tones of bourbon and vanilla was fantastic.  A wonderful, wonderful pot of tea!  

BUT
We were the only 3 people in the place for two and a half hours, and the wait service was STILL sub-par.  She didn't clear our plates.  She didn't check back at all - not even to see if we needed refills or if the tea had gotten too cold or too strong.  We had to call out to her.  She was too even unmotivated to talk to the person in the kitchen - even though I was asking her direct questions about the food that the waitress couldn't answer.  And she sat us at a very small table for 3, with every other table open in the entire restaurant.  It really was a nice table, but there was not enough room for our food and tea.  Really, it annoyed me because we could have sat at a four-top and been more comfortable but that wasn't given as an option.

The food was fine, but nothing to write home about.  The savory scone was a bit too peppery, the peanut butter scone was very nice but small, and the crumpets were too hard to cut through.  

And the price for what we got was nuts - though I admit they did give us each our own pot of tea, whereas I'm used to sharing with my friends at other tea places.

Overall, I was disappointed and won't return.  I would, however, highly recommend this place if what you really want is a great pot of tea and a nice chat in a lovely atmosphere.  

Wish I had better news!
author: Cassie C.

description: So overall this was an ok high tea experience for my wife and I.  It was a bit of a mixed bag.  Definitely not a "white glove" experience, but I knew that coming in.  Arriving straight from the airport, they were kind enough to offer to store our luggage while we ate.  We got the Covenant Garden and Knightsbridge meals.  Good things, food was generally pretty good.  Things tasted homemade and I liked my mango tea (although the waitress told us that the wrong teas were in the tea pots).  Of particular enjoyment was the crumpet, scone and tuna and egg sandwich.  Petition four was a little bit dense. "fresh fruit" was pretty scant but pretty.  They also have hardly any decaf non-herbal teas, which is a little bit strange.  Overall, it was an enjoyable, somewhat pricey experience.
author: Michael C.

description:
Was gifted a Sherlock Holmes book years ago but never opened it till binge reading from cover to cover earlier this week. Totally into it.

So you know when I saw "Yo Holmes! It's Watson" tea on the menu, it immediately usurped the top spot on my to-food list. Showed up the very next morning #norsvp for #satunchdaybrunchday - s'how I roll, suckas.

(^_^) Yo Holmes! It's Watson Tea
dopest. tea. ever.

(^_^) Fish & Chips Sando
#datcrunchdoe

(^_^) Garlic Shrimp Sando
Unspicy, so stop worrying.

(^_^) Curry Chicken Sando
Surprise sweet. Raisins?

(^_^) Salmon Mousse Sando
Light, smooth taste. #twss

(^_^) Music
Coltrane, Ella Fitzgeezy, etc!

(-_^) Sausage Rolls
Flaky good pastry.

Shout out to #tokenblackfamily bc #diversity. #blackbrunchesmatter

Also shout out to #heftychick server & all the larrrge layyydieeeees out there! Skinny beezys better start ordering quadruple tier sandwich towers. And not to share with your 10 friends either - I'm talking about per person, trick. #what ;p #partiallyjk
author: Dan B.

description: Every time I come to San Francisco to visit a friend we have a tea service somewhere. Dartealing was cute and kitschy with a great selection of teas. I was however, very disappointed that they did not have honey to add to my tea.  The only options were sugar and agave?!  Call me picky, but who doesn't  want a splash of honey in a cup of good Earle Grey? The savory items, like the quiche and sausage/croissant roll were very good. The scones and clotted cream were delish, but the other sweets were average. All in all a fun afternoon, but not my favorite tea service in the City by the Bay. Pinkies up!
author: Eva W.

description: It was okay for what it is. Im sure I would prefer somewhere else better. I got the winter afternoon tea for $34. The selection was okay and the tea was okay. My friend had asked the waitress for a refill of tea and the waitress was like okay and just walked away. Overall,everything was okay.
author: Wesley K.

description:
I'm a big fan of the institution of afternoon tea, and I'm slowly making the rounds around SF, having first tried the Laurel Court afternoon tea at the Fairmont Hotel, and now checking out Dartealing Lounge. 

The decor was adorable, with the cutest teapots and plates. The tea did not disappoint! My friend and I both opted for the Covent Garden Tea service for 2 (slightly cheaper than when ordering separately) which included mainly savory items (a mini spanikopita (sp?), cucumber cup filled with tuna, and your choice of 2 types of sandwiches, cut into quarters) as well as a scone, a mini cake, a cookie, and a petit four. The scone was still warm, and served with a dish of clotted cream and a little jar of jam, yum! 

Between us, we ordered the turkey and pesto, fish and chips, curried chicken, and tuna sandwiches. The selection was pretty diverse, and they all sounded good so it was hard to pick! I thought they were all tasty, although be fore-warned that the turkey pesto sandwich goes a little heavy on the mayo. The fish and chips has literal potato chips on a sandwich with some breaded fish, very unique!

For my tea, I ordered Her Majesty's Secret Service, which had a lovely creamy texture and a slightly buttery flavor. It was actually a good amount of food, and I was definitely too full to eat any dinner after, so come hungry! It was relatively quiet when we came on a Sat afternoon, but that might have been due to the July 4th holiday, so it might still be a good idea to grab a rez. 

I'd definitely come back, a great spot for catching up with friends! A more affordable option to the decadent ambiance at the Laurel Court =).
author: Vivian L.

description:
Afternoon tea spot. It's so cute and warm inside. The ambience is great! Decorations were sweet and charming!

My friend and I got the Covent Garden Tea service. After reading reviews we got:

Tea
Breakfast candy black tea: it had no flavor behind it and what flavor there was left a gross after taste to it. I don't know why its popular in yelp reviews.
Parisian Earl Grey: really good! Classic tea to get!

Sandwiches
Smoked salmon mousse and fill: good
Fresh cucumber and herbs: good
Dartealing curried chicken: good
Berries and cream: weird texture for a sandwich; it was kind of soupy and gross

Petit four good; scone good; shortbread cookie good

Tea cake of the day: carrot cake. I love carrot cake but this was just too sweet and there was a crunchy topping that didn't agree with my taste preferences.

Staff seemed super busy as the place was packed.
author: Mimi T.

description:
My family picked Dartealing to celebrate our annual high tea get together in mid-January. We made a reservation a few months in advance, which required a $60 deposit. 
They were still serving their holiday menu and it was $34 per person for sandwiches, scones, desserts, and a pot of tea. 
After our tea service, I left a bit disappointed. The scones we had were almost hard as rocks and the clotted cream had a slight sour taste. The sandwiches were okay though there weren't equal amounts of each sandwich to share. For example, some people had 2 of each sandwich and some had 3. Our server also seemed kind of lazy. She first served our pots of teas then as we settled in, she later informed us to make room for the tiers of food, which I didn't understand why she couldn't have done so. Then she went back in the kitchen to grab the food for our table. Later on, she had us combine some of the items onto one plate and hand her the empty plates to clear some space. Again, I feel like she could've done this herself.
author: Anita W.

description:
For someone who's a tea snob and loooooves the High Tea experience, Dartealing Lounge is amazing. The Curried chicken salad with mango chutney, curried egg salad, and cucumber arugula are amazing tea sandwiches.

I've been to many tea rooms across the bay area and they have the best food and tea!
Scones are killer, my favorite is the white chocolate lavender. 
Black teas are amazing and strong :) 

Staff is amazing and welcome me each time I come.
author: Mone J.

description:
Any guy who tells you he despises afternoon tea either: a) is lying or b) has never experienced it before. I have come to learn that men love finger foods, and there was no shortage of testosterone during my visit here. 

For $48, I enjoyed the Afternoon Tea Service for Two. The turkey & pesto cream and brie, pepper jelly, green apple sandwiches were especially delectable, and the warm scones were served fresh out of the oven. I gargled some Snickerdoodle black tea between bites while watching people's boyfriends gingerly sipping out of their teacups and fingering their cute edibles.

Next time your man refuses to accompany you to afternoon tea, be sure to tell him about the amount of fingering and eating that's involved in the experience. Let me know how it works out.
author: Suany W.

description:
My friend and I love the idea of catching up over afternoon tea and this place is perfect for that!

Dartealing Lounge is located just outside of the busy downtown area. I personally thought the area was a little bit sketchy, but the streets are busy so no worries.

On the outside, the little shop is a bit plain and nondescript so if you weren't looking for it, you might walk past it. Inside is a completely different story. The little tea shop is decorated in Victorian decor. There are gorgeous tea pots and cups, all of which were different! So it was fun to look around and study the different designs.

They have so many options on their menu! My friend and I ended up choosing the Bloomsbury Tea Service. Each set comes with eight mini sandwiches (you get to pick two flavors), a scone, a shortbread cookie, a slice of tea cake, a salad, a macaron, and a entire pot of tea. So between the two of us, there's a ton to eat.

We each got a pot of tea. We ordered the Earl de Versailles which has hints of lavender. I thought it was the perfect combination of flavor. The other pot is Currant's the New Black which contains black currants and other berries. This was just as good, especially if you're a fan of fruity infused teas.

Honey lavender cream tea sandwich - I was a little disappointed with this one since it seemed so simple and not very lavender-y. There was lavender with cream and a touch of honey on bread. Some bites had lavender and others didn't.

Berry Cream tea sandwich - This was similar to honey lavender cream, but there was so much more flavor. The berries were jam like and packed with flavor.

Fish and Chips tea sandwich - We thought this was an interesting combination for tea, but oh my god, it was soo good. It was savory, slightly crunchy, and a perfect way to balance out the sweets.

Dartealing Curried Chicken - while the curry flavor is there, I was slightly disappointed with this sandwich. There was something about it that I didn't like as much as the other sandwiches.

The scones were delicious but really dense. I think this should be saved for last. After eating this scone, I was completely full.

The macaron was disappointing. I actually couldn't quite tell what flavor it was and it was sweet without being special. I expect a lot more from macaron.

The lavender shortbread cookie was so amazing. It had a hint of lavender in every buttery bite.

The poppyseed tea cake has the texture of pound cake. I thought it was really good. Slightly sweet and perfect with tea.

After everything, I didn't even get to the salad, but it looked really fresh.

Overall, I'd recommend this place if you're looking for a place for a girl's day out, or a little get together. It wasn't crowded on a Sunday afternoon, and we could sit and talk without worrying about having to leave in a hurry.
author: Andrea G.

description:
Looove the fun and casual vibe here! 
There are 2 tea packages you can pick. 
Handmade menus are lovely!
You can buy the teas here to bring one.
Parking is easy which is fabulous for SF!
author: Veranna N.

description: They didnt have a non dairy option like other tea rooms. They also didnt provide lemon curd, strawberry preserves and clotted cream like other traditional tea rooms. I called in for a same day reservation and asked for a 130 or 2pm time slot. They said they would be able to accommodate me at 2pm. I arrived at 2pm and the entire restaurant was empty with one table of 4 people. They also have a 14 dollar minimum, which I get and I dont mind. So I ordered a pair of sandwiches and pair of scones in addition to the king tea for 1. (We had 2 adults and my little guy). The scones were hard and the sandwiches were mediocre at best. The desserts were also sub par as compared to other tea rooms as well. The waitress reccomended I order another pot of tea to avoid a split/sharing charge, so I did as well. When the bill came, she charged a split/sharing fee because my toddler CHILD shared my tea!! Wasnt exactly pleased, options weren't great and not a huge selection of teas. Most likely will not be back.
author: Linda P.

description:
Afternoon Tea is a lovely way to while away the hours of the late afternoon, breathing deeply and relaxing over a delicious cuppa, as well as nibbling at some tasty accompaniments!  Dartealing Tea Lounge does a lovely job of helping you achieve this calm and cozy bit of rest in the middle of your day!

Once you enter from the busy streets of SoMa, your mood is immediately transformed by your cozy, quaint, and traditional English surroundings.  There are tasteful decorations of fine china, vintage lamps, upholstered furniture, and a variety of low tables between, giving the impression that you've entered someone's living room or parlour.

You'll be seated according to the size of your party, of course, but especially when they aren't busy, they'll generally be happy to accommodate you at any table/sitting area you request.  

This is not a formal tea service, so don't go expecting that:  Your utensils will be in a basket or cutlery tin on your table for you to help yourself to, your teacups and plates will be mismatched, and may not be fine bone china.  And when your pot of tea arrives, you will be told how much longer to let it steep before you pour it yourself.  This casualness is comforting and expected at this price range...but if you're used to higher end tea service, where your tea is poured for you, etc., this may be an adjustment.

You'll be given a choice of tea sandwiches to go with the specific tea service you ordered.  My personal favorite, by far, is the Dartealing Curried Chicken!  This is their take on the uber-traditional British favorite "Coronation Chicken Salad".  For those not familiar with this concept, it's basically a chicken salad with curry powder (not "hot" spicy, just flavorful) and mango chutney with the addition of plumped raisins.  

Be aware that at Dartealing, most of their tea sandwich fillings are a paste of the ingredients, as though all the items were put in a food processor and pulsed a few times (which is, I'm guessing, how they're made).  So while they are tasty, it can give the impression of being a spread on bread, with a gooier consistency than most of the tea sandwiches I'm used to being served at other tea salons.  

Also, the teas themselves are often brewed too weak for my preference, because they don't put enough tea leaves into the pots for my taste.  Maybe they've never had any complaints, or maybe this is a cost-cutting measure?

The miniature desserts are a-ok, nothing to write home about...but this is generally my feeling on mini desserts as part of afternoon tea.  For me, there's so much else that's sweet, to finish with desserts is gilding the lily!  That is a personal preference, though, and not a knock on Dartealing.

The big highlight of Dartealing's tea service?!  THE SCONES!!!! They are light, flaky, flavorful, and always very fresh!  Served with fruit preserves and "royal cream" (not quite the thick clotted or devon cream I'm used to), they are to die for!!!  The scones come in different flavors every time I go, and I assume they rotate regularly.  Be aware that if you want lemon curd (from a jar, not fresh) to go with your scone, they will charge you extra.

This tea lounge is WHEELCHAIR-ACCESSIBLE, which is such a relief and so nice!  Best of all, if you use a mobility scooter but don't want to take it to your table, the employees will let you park it in the front foyer of the restaurant without any hesitation!  They will also run out to help you with the front door if they see you about to enter or exit!!

Be aware that while they close at 6 pm, last seating is at 4:30 pm, and by 5:30 pm they might be starting to turn off some lights around the back of the store.  If you are aiming for 4:30 pm but are running 5-10 minutes late, you can call them and ask them to put in your order in advance, which they have been generous enough to do for me on several occasions in the past.  It is best, though, to try to arrive on-time, though, as tea service is usually made to order and isn't something that one can rush through...this is especially true for larger parties!

Dartealing also has some china pieces for sale in the front of the store, a fact I've taken advantage of in the past (hello, hot pink tea cups!!!).  And they also sell scones to-go...they aren't cheap, but they're delicious, and a great fresh baked good to bring with you to a bridal or baby shower!

Dartealing remains one of my favorite afternoon relaxation haunts in San Francisco, and I heartily recommend it to anyone looking to enjoy a wonderful, quaint, British tradition!!!
author: Amy L.

description:
**My 300th review**

Sorry folks, I would love to start off this year with a positive review, but unfortunately after the experience today, the other good reviews will have to wait. After this,a well deserved wonderful review of Lovejoy's is in order.

Short summary: Owner / "Chef" Pauline is rude not open to listening to experiences or short comings of the visit, or feedback.  Sandwiches lacking filling, no flavor, desserts stale. Other yelpers also say Pauline tried to insult them. DON'T come here, go to Lovejoy's!! Tell yo Mama, yo Grandma , the guy at the liquor store, heck, scream it running down the street, "DO NOT GO TO DARTEALING!!" 

The decor and low ceilings gives Dartealing a warm and cozy feeling. Immediately after sitting down with my girls we were complimenting the set up. Decor ALONE does not create ambiance, service plays a huge roll. Most negative reviews are about servers attitude

Teas:
Lychees in Dreams-Oolong 5/5 Charged for refills
From Pear to Eternity 4/5
Royal Earl Grey 0/5 too spicy 
Jasmine & Jade 1/5 free dim sum tea 

Sandwiches:
smoked salmon mousse & dill 4/5 good, barely had any filling inside.
spicy garlic shrimp 2/5 what spice no flavor?
turkey & pesto cream 3/5 heavy on the oil 
tuna, egg, olives a la nicoise 0/5 olives do not pair well, overpowering taste

Dessert: Kirsten (referred to by yelpers as eeyore, resemblance uncanny) rushed over our platter vs how kindly and slowly she went over the tiers with the table next to us right. I did nibble on a stale 2016 chocolate cake bar that tasted like refrigerator frostbite, and a scone which was very dry on the outside and doughy on the inside. LOVEJOY, Pauline said you buy their scones.

Cake cutting fee $2pp Eeyore watched to make sure we did not eat any during the photo opp (yea We saw you creepin)

Bathrooms: filthy

Reservation w/ $60 deposit for a party of 9, and had 8, we would pay for the 9th, but no big deal ,we will pay for the extra portion. We were happily sipping on our Lychee tea and the sandwiches arrive, totaling 64.  They decided to charge us for 9 but gave us portions for 8. After asking if it was correct, server confirmed we would only pay for 8. Was it because we caught you skimping us? Bait and switch! ( I would later find out this inquiry would deem me and my entire party "Intimidating" - straight from the horse's mouth, Pauline)

Immediately after,the service changed. All employees huddled in the back and all tables left unattended for 10 mins. Once dispersed, We noticed Kirsten, not our server, giving us looks, staring, awkwardly dead giveaway that the hens had been cackling about our group. She's hard to miss since she's dressed as if she rolled out of bed in her Jammie Jams (baggy Tshirt.) We shrugged her off until she slammed both the desserts and the cream on our table, hard enough to rattle the silverware.

Autogratuity, a whopping 20%- labeled as a "service charge" but our server clarified its gratuity. We were not advise before arriving or after arriving there was any additional charge? The service charge needs to be stated before the meal, and if a gratuity, we are allowed to tip based on our service. This was not 20% service. Talking behind the back of your patrons, leaving tables unattended for long periods of time, charging us for service of 9 and serving 8, rude treatment and stares from staff. 

IF based on the service (my server),  and overall I would have rated 3 stars. I wouldn't have even left a review, not worth my time. I figured a mental note not to return would suffice. Then Pauline , yelled aggressively across the room waiving her pointer finger in the air Sha NAY NAY style "WHO IS SHARON I NEED TO TALK TO HER" (Like a child on a schoolyard instigating for someone for taking their swing) I compare this to a child because the entire encounter lacked common sense, maturity, and professionalism. This now made Dartealing review worthy. Once she reached the table, she slammed the receipt down and started ranting about how our group was making her servers feel intimidated, and how we were the ones at fault and how oh, "that's why she owns a tea shop and I don't." How is this relevant, or constructive ? All her rants and attempts to intimidate me failed. I gave her honest valid feedback of the issues I've stated in this review and more. All which she could not deny. She accused me of predetermining my experience , and I asked how she came to that decision ,nothing but crickets..  Her employees are a reflection of her, now I understand the service.

Anyways Congrats Pauline you made this place a must review.You will probably reply my review like how you bickered with me in front of your other guests. Embarrassing much? We see the way you reply other negative reviews, and wish we had taken those reviews more seriously. Boo I ain't the one to bully. Maybe you should just stay in the kitchen.

I still enjoyed my birthday because I have the best friends in the world, no thanks to Dartealin
author: Sharon N.

description:
Had the afternoon tea service for 3 and tried the following sandwiches:

1. Smoked Salmon Mousse & Dill - yummy but kinda bummed that they don't have a sandwich option with actual salmon vs. salmon mousse
2. Dartealing Curried Chicken - didn't like this. expected the spice to be more "asian curry" taste versus "indian curry"
3. Ham and Horseradish Cheddar - A OK
4. Turkey and Pesto Cream - Good but nothing amazing
5. Brie, Pepper Jelly, Green Apple - Kinda weird tasting. Not a fan.

Scones - AMAZING. I loved them. Crumbly, buttery, and not too dense. Wouldn't mind going back to this place just to have the scones again.

Tea cookies- Good, kind of reminds me of the costco butter cookies that come out during Xmas

Petit fours - The usual, overly sweet, and nothing out of the ordinary

Toffee pudding - First time trying it. Not my cup of tea because I don't really like caramel and toffee kind of just tastes like a sweeter version of caramel to me. Was surprised that the pudding actually comes out warm.

Service was EXTREMELY SLOW the day we were there. They were busy and I understand there's only ONE server so she can only go so fast but I don't get why they just don't hire more workers...It's not rocket science. You expect a ton of customers to come in during the weekends, why don't you get another server?
author: June Y.

description:
This is one of the cutest tea rooms I've been to so far! It definitely has the feel of an authentic tea service, and has a pretty good selection of food and teas to choose from. I highly recommend making a reservation as far in advance as possible because it's a pretty popular place and slots fill up pretty quickly.

I came with a group of four, and we decided to get two different tea services which each served two people. I selected the Covent Garden Tea, which came with cucumber cups, two sandwiches per person, scones, petit fours, the cake of the day, and shortbread cookies. For the sandwiches I tried the smoked salmon mousse and dill and the turkey cranberry which I believe was a seasonal special. For my tea I got the snickerdoodle, which really lived up to its name! All of the treats were delicious, and surprisingly more filling than I thought they would be since I ended up having leftovers to take home.

I will say the service can be a little iffy. Our waitress let us know at around 2:25 that the next reservation for our table was at 2:30, which didn't give us much time to prepare to finish up, so we felt really rushed towards the end. Since afternoon tea is something that's meant to be relaxing and enjoyable, It would have been nice to have an earlier warning. We were pretty turned off by this, but luckily the rest of the service had been good enough for me to let it slide. I definitely recommend Dartealing if you're searching for a nice afternoon tea!
author: Jaymie S.

description:
Fine but incredibly overpriced. They have a very complicated menu system that involves a LOT of additional fees. Fees for sharing (not plating separately, just both eating off the same tray), minimum price per person, fees for splitting tabs. The food and tea were both good but just did not justify the price. The decor was a little fussy but cute, although a little at odds with the waitress dressed in athleisure wear (also not what I'm expecting at $20-$40pp restaurant).

If you can stomach the price I could see this being a fun place to bring a kid, especially if you did a full tea service. I wouldn't really recommend it for anything else though.
author: Rene M.

description:
First tea affair ever and it was relaxing for a Sunday fun day! 

Their tea selections and choices that are set were very delectable!  I loved their bakeries - scrumptious to the palate indeed!

The decor exuded the Victorian style and it was a pleasure on just being pleasantly there while sipping on tea and munching on petite tastings.

It is a place to simply just be or to invite some company or a company for some chit chatter over tea!

Would you like to share some tea with me?
author: Tiffany D.

description: We came here for my birthday lunch.  We had previously been to Lovejoys, and I liked it better. Dartealing seemed dark and somewhat crowded.  The menu requires some explanation, such as how many sandwiches come with tea service.  We were a party of 3, and our table quickly filled up with tea pots, sandwich service, etc.   and there was very little room to move without taking a chance on spilling.  The servers seemed somewhat impatient, and there was no special mention or treat for my birthday.  The good points were the tasty finger sandwiches and the generous amounts of tea and cocoa.  The humus cucumber bite was quite spicy.  The petit fours were not spectacular.
author: Becca H.

description:
This is definitely one of my worst tea experience. The food was mediocre and service was just HORRIBLE!!!! First of all, the water they used for the tea was lukewarm and there wasn't much of a flavor to the tea (I could have done a better job brewing the tea from home). Secondly, we asked the lady that works there for more cucumber cups and her attitude was just so rude. She didn't set the tiered plates right so the plate in the second tier fell off the table and she was giving us attitudes and never offer to replace them. We had a big group so gratuity (20%) was included but if we had to pay that separately, I would have left a very bad tip. 

Definitely do NOT recommend anyone to come here and I will not come back again
author: Christine J.

description:
So my friend and I came and spent 3 hours here. We did the early weekday special which included scones, our pick of two sandwiches, some sweets and of course a pot of tea for a low cost (sorry I can't recall how much right now). I'm writing this review about 3 weeks later so I can't recall specific details other than the delicious curry sandwich and.. Yep I forgot what the other things are.

The reason my rating is 5 stars is because this place is comfortable and allowed us to truly enjoy our lengthly stay. It was priced fairly and gave us what we wanted... Tea time. 

I'll be back.
author: Kristy F.

description: This is my new favorite high tea spot in the city. It's on a particularly busy street so I would just Uber it here. I used to go to Lovejoy's but it was booked through Jan so we decided to try this place instead and I can gladly say, I am so glad we did. The decor inside is so, so charming. We got the Covent and the Chelsea and although the food took about 20 min to come out, it was all so fresh & delicious. From the sandwiches, the crumpets, the macaroons, we loved it all. I got the strawberry green tea and it was amazing as well. The servers are knowledgeable and super sweet. Love this place, can't wait to come back!!
author: Tania S.

description: What a cute place! I had such a great experience with with my girlfriend's. I ordered "Chelsea's​" sweets and choose the First Date on the Nile which is a lovely black tea. My friends ordered one of the other tea services and a few items off of the ala carte menu. We enjoyed all our items and absolutely loved the tea! (The scone was a little dry but good flavor) The decor is perfect, mixed tea sets, soft music in the background. Over all great experience and I'm excited to go back!
author: Summer T.

description:
This place is a wonderful place to catch up with friends. The environment and couches are cute and comfortable. I would recommend making a reservation because when I got there people with no reservations either left after being tired of waiting or waited for a while. 

My favorites includes the scones and the cucumber finger sandwiches. 

The bottomless tea sounds like a good deal but it's really a lot of liquid so I'm not sure if it's a better deal than just one pot.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I've had Dartealing bookmarked for awhile but finally made my way there last week! My friend and I were strolling through SOMA on our way to another restaurant when we walked by Dartealing and were lucky enough to get seated without a reservation! With that said, I would definitely recommend making a reservation because it was pretty busy.

Dartealing offers several different tea services, some including salads or crumpets and some without. We opted for the Covent Garden Tea ($56 for 2 people) which was a mix of small sandwiches and petit fours and of course - scones (a MUST have for afternoon tea). I really liked that we were able to pick two sandwiches were person so we were able to try four different sandwiches of our choice! They offer 20 different sandwiches with a variety of flavors like seafood, meat, vegetarian or sweet. So depending on what you're craving that day, you can pick your flavor! The sandwiches tasted fresh and the scones were hot when served. I did notice that we were not served jam with our scones but we did get clotted cream.

There was a large tea selection as well, I picked the Earl de Versailles which was a mix of earl grey and lavender. Absolute fragrant heaven! I love that they have several earl grey options here for earl grey lovers like me.

Service was okay. There was only one server and she was busy with a full house but she was friendly. Definitely plan on spending some time here since the service is on the slower side. The decor was cute, mismatched yet matched, vintage-shabby-sorta-chic. It was a cozy atmosphere and I would've preferred a better lit and more modern atmosphere but I would visit again.
author: Andrea P.

description: I've been here several times over the years, and it was always good. While I understand being short-staffed on a busy Sunday with two large parties, serving food to a table of 12 WHO GOT HERE THIRTY MINUTES AFTER WE ORDERED before a table of 3 is unacceptable. Their food was ordered later and in larger quantities, there was no excuse to serve out of order. One spoon for the whole table with seven knives and forks. I came here because they had great options for sandwhiched that DIDN'T have cream cheese, sour cream, or mayo. This time - every single one! Your server looked at me like I was stupid when I asked if any of the ones we picked didn't have cream cheese. No reason why I should assume "meatball and parmesaen" would have sour cream.
author: Christina R.

description:
This review is a little longer overdue, but necessary.

A couple months ago my friends and I hosted a bridal shower.  We made reservations on a Saturday right when it opened.  The lounge stated that we would only have 20 minutes prior to opening to setup.  We arrived 30 minutes prior to opening because we wanted to maximize the time we had to setup.  We noticed that someone was inside and knocked hoping to get a few extra minutes, but we were completely ignored until another worker arrived right at 20 minutes prior to opening.  Despite being promised 20 minutes to setup we had less than 15 minutes to do so.  While setting up the owner rudely stated that 2 of my tiny girlfriends should not be standing on a bench because it was the 1700s or something like that.  (Um, side note, the bench is big enough to fit 4-5 full grown adults... so 2 of my girlfriends would no way break this bench.)  The owner pretty much complained about every decoration we had or where it was placed.  I would understand the owner's complaints if we had not informed the owner prior to the event, but we cleared it with her.  Talk about customer service...

On to the actual bridal shower... we made reservations for 25 people, but Dartealing only setup for 22 people.  (Why even make a reservation when the setup is not correct?!)  The tea service didn't being until 45 minutes AFTER our reservation time.  Keep in mind, the max reservation time at Dartealing is 2 hours.  Once most of the party had a round of of tea, the food came out (this was probably close to an hour + into the reservation).  The sandwiches were decent (i.e. hit-or-miss) - I enjoyed the curried chicken & chutney and the brie, pepper jelly & apple.  The teas were okay - none were really memorable with the exception of the cabana boy.  There was a fruity tea that was too strong and fragrant and the earl grey was quite disappointing.  The dessert selection was varied enough for everyone to enjoy something of her choosing.  The presentation of the food and teas was typical of a high tea lounge.  Honestly nothing special.  Kinda expensive all things considered.

This space is tiny.  This place feels so cluttered to the point it looks unorganized and dirty.  There were some cobwebs by the window area...  When cleaning up, the owner again angrily mentioned that we shouldn't be standing on the bench...

The workers didn't seem to like what they were doing (i.e. no smiles) and at minimum was decent at times.  The customer service was below average.  Unless I'm proven otherwise, I will not be recommending this place to friends nor returning (so I guess it'll be difficult to be proven otherwise... whatevs).  Just disappointing.  The bride-to-be enjoyed it and, despite the mediocrity of this place, it justifies the one-star.

I'm not from SF, but I'm sure there are better places to spend your time and money for high tea.
author: Sola L.

description:
This place is pretty great. I've been looking for a tea place in the city for awhile, and Dartealing Lounge is definitely one of the more popular options that has popped up in my search, so after walking around SOMA and Portrero Hill for an afternoon, the SO and I decided to check out Dartealing Lounge for an afternoon.

It seems like a family owned place -- we saw a couple of kids helping out with some of the dishes which is cute. It's so overly Victorian and quintessential afternoon tea. It's fantastic. You have the floral stuff, the prints, the tea cozies, everything you could possibly imagine in your typical tea setting. We saw a minimum charge for each person and got confused so we ended up each getting an entire pot of tea which was WAY too much for two people lol. The tea was fairly good though - I had the Jasmine and Jade and the SO had the Rice-Too-Crispy which was also quite good. We also split the scones of the day which were some lemon flavored scones.

Overall, the tea was quite delicious -- I actually really enjoyed the rice tea quite a bit. Scones were also pretty delicious. 

This is an awesome place to just sit around and chat while enjoying some afternoon tea service. They have a couple more fancy, fuller sets of afternoon teas as well. Service is super friendly here, and it's a relatively quiet and peaceful place to spend the afternoon. Saw some kids sitting in a corner doing homework, so definitely a nice offbeat afternoon.

tldr; great place for afternoon tea! decent price and good tea -- highly recommend!
author: Jasmine X.

description: I've been here three times in under a year. The food is amazing the staff is great. Wait times are not bad considering all of the preparation that goes towards each tea service. I recommend this place to everyone. All of the sandwiches I've had are good. And the scones are to die for. I wish I could eat here every single day.
author: Yvonne E.

description:
This is such a hidden gem in soma. Came here with my boyfriend around 1130 on a Saturday morning without a reservation and luckily they were able to squeeze us in despite having a couple larger parties already there. The decor here is adorable yet typical of a tea room, but the tea cups and saucers are all mismatched and add a little quirkiness to the vintage ambiance which I loved. 

We decided on the covent garden tea service which included cucumber cups, little tartlets, 8 tea sandwiches (choose 4 different ones), petit fours, shortbread cookies, and two scones. I usually come to tea rooms for the atmosphere and I don't usually have too high of expectations for the food, but I would go back here just for the scones alone. One was a lemon and lavender I believe and the other was an Oreo scone. Both were still warm and soft on the inside while still having that crisp outside that I've come to love about a scone. Now I'm no scone expert but you just have to trust me and try them! The tea sandwiches were pretty good as well, and I would recommend the turkey pesto and the fish and chips! Stay away from the salmon mousse, this was the only part of my brunch I was thoroughly disappointed with. Sadly we got pretty full off the scones and the sandwiches (surprisingly)  so I only nibbled at the desserts, but the bites I did have were awesome. The tea was good as well but I was disappointed they didn't have the blueberry one in stock. Guess this gives me an excuse to go back though :) overall, a little pricey but your extra dollar spent will leave your belly full and happy.
author: Sam L.

description: Came here with my family.  We asked to be seated at one of the tables for three people but the manager/owner said all tables that were not occupied were already reserved.   Hence, we were at one of the sofas with a coffee table.  Not as comfy and wish she had been a little gracious and accommodating.  Sandwiches and tea were ok.  Would I go back? No.
author: P S.

description: Came here with a group of 6 under a reservation. Very cute decor and set up. Service was questionably slow, it was difficult to get the waitress' attention when we wanted to order, though I suppose it's meant to be a laid back and sit for several hours experience. The sandwiches were actually very delicious. We enjoyed them a bit more than all the desserts and teas. The pricing is not too bad comparing to other high tea establishments, though this one has a much more casual environment, with our nearby tables being groups of friends as well as families.
author: Elisa L.

description:
When my friends from the city started raving about tea rooms, I was completely confused. But after visiting Dartealing Lounge, I totally get the appeal. Dartealing Lounge allows you to get away from the busy city life of San Francisco and pretend you're an idyllic character in a Lewis Caroll novel.

I absolutely loved the décor in the shop, it was adorable and quaint. My friend and I shared a basic tea set with 2 pots of tea, 2 scones and 2 muffins which came with cream and lemon jam. We shared the Cherry Moon tea - my personal favorite it was so light, fruity and delicious I could have finished a whole pot on my own. We also had the Parisian Earl Grey. I like Earl grey teas and this one was very fragrant, but had a slight bitter aftertaste.

A slight downer is that there seems to be just one server who is nice but a little bit distracted, so it may take some time to be served.

All in all, I really enjoyed the décor and concept of Dartealing Lounge, it is definitely a place I would not hesitate to take my friends to, and I would love to hang out at. The teas were also superb and I can't wait to go back and try more of them.
author: Sarah T.

description:
A great place for a special occasion treat. The decor was English tea room but not over the top. Even the holiday decor was refined.
